get.description: Lists all of the user applications.

parameters.name: skip
parameters.description: The number of entries to skip. Default value is 0.

parameters.name: take
parameters.description: The number of entries to return. Maximum page size is 500. Default is 100.

200.description: A list of the user applications.

post.description: Creates a new LUIS app.

requestBody.description: A model containing Name, Description (optional), Culture, Usage Scenario (optional), Domain (optional) and initial version ID (optional) of the application. Default value for the version ID is 0.1. Note: the culture cannot be changed after the app is created.

201.description: The ID of the created application.

201.description: The ID of the created application.

200.description: Returns a list of all domains and their intents/entities representation for a specific culture.

get.description: Returns the available endpoint deployment regions and URLs.

get.description: Gets the list of user emails that have permissions to access your application.

200.description: The list includes a single owner. All collaborators are listed in the emails array.

put.description: Replaces the current users access list with the one sent in the body. If an empty list is sent, all access to other users will be removed.

requestBody.description: A model containing a list of user's email addresses.

post.description: Adds a user to the allowed list of users to access this LUIS application. Users are added using their email address.

requestBody.description: A model containing the user's email address.

delete.description: Removes a user from the allowed list of users to access this LUIS application. Users are removed using their email address.

get.description: Gets the training status of all models (intents and entities) for the specified LUIS app. You must call the train API to train the LUIS app before you call this API to get training status. "appID" specifies the LUIS app ID. "versionId" specifies the version number of the LUIS app. For example, "0.1".

200.description: A successful response provides an array of training status details for a LUIS app that you submitted for training. Each element in the response array provides training status for a model (intent or entity) in the LUIS app. Note: Training status is not provided for prebuilt entities because they are pretrained. The "modelId" property identifies which intent or entity the training status corresponds to. To get the name and type of each model, use the models API which has a request URL in this format: https://westus.api.cognitive.microsoft.com/luis/api/v2.0/apps/{appId}/versions/{versionId}/models The details property for each model can contain the following fields: "statusId": An integer from 0 to 3 that corresponds to the value of the status field. "status": A string with one of the following values: Success, UpToDate, InProgress, Fail. If the status is Fail, the "failureReason" property provides the reason for failure. "exampleCount": The number of examples used for training. In the case of the None intent or prebuilt domain intents and entities, this number includes example provided internally by the system as well as examples you added to your LUIS app. "failureReason": A string that indicates the reason training failed.  The value "FewLabels" means that no labeled examples were provided for training. "trainingDateTime": A string indicating the time the model was last trained. The value uses the ISO 8601 format for representing times in UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) with a UTC designator (Z), for example: "2017-08-10T01:08:34Z".

post.description: Sends a training request for a version of a specified LUIS app. This POST request initiates a request asynchronously. To determine whether the training request is successful, submit a GET request to get training status. Note: The application version is not fully trained unless all the models (intents and entities) are trained successfully or are up to date. To verify training success, get the training status at least once after training is complete.

202.description: This response indicates the initial training status.

culture.description: The culture for the new application. It is the language that your app understands and speaks. E.g.: "en-us". Note: the culture cannot be changed after the app is created.

domain.description: The domain for the new application. Optional. E.g.: Comics.

initialVersionId.description: The initial version ID. Optional. Default value is: "0.1"

name.description: The name for the new application.

usageScenario.description: Defines the scenario for the new application. Optional. E.g.: IoT.

JSONEntity.description: Exported Model - Extracted Entity from utterance.

activated.description: Indicates if the feature is enabled.

mode.description: An exchangeable phrase list feature are serves as single feature to the LUIS underlying training algorithm. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt. Think of an exchangeable as a synonyms list. A non-exchangeable phrase list feature has all the phrases in the list serve as separate features to the underlying training algorithm. So, if you your phrase list feature contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-exchangeable phrase list feature as an additional bag of words that you are willing to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. Think of a non-exchangeable as set of different words. Default value is true.

words.description: List of comma-separated phrases that represent the Phraselist.

activated.description: Indicates if the Pattern feature is enabled.

isExchangeable.description: An exchangeable phrase list feature are serves as single feature to the LUIS underlying training algorithm. It is used as a lexicon lookup feature where its value is 1 if the lexicon contains a given word or 0 if it doesnt. Think of an exchangeable as a synonyms list. A non-exchangeable phrase list feature has all the phrases in the list serve as separate features to the underlying training algorithm. So, if you your phrase list feature contains 5 phrases, they will be mapped to 5 separate features. You can think of the non-exchangeable phrase list feature as an additional bag of words that you are willing to add to LUIS existing vocabulary features. Think of a non-exchangeable as set of different words. Default value is true.
